13177 
13178 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13179 unsigned int
13180 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::n_used_vertices() const
13181 {
13182  return std::count(vertices_used.begin(), vertices_used.end(), true);
13183 }
13184 
13185 
13186 
13187 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13188 const std::vector<bool> &
13189 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::get_used_vertices() const
13190 {
13191  return vertices_used;
13192 }
13193 
13194 
13195 
13196 template <>
13197 unsigned int
13198 Triangulation<1, 1>::max_adjacent_cells() const
13199 {
13200  return 2;
13201 }
13202 
13203 
13204 
13205 template <>
13206 unsigned int
13207 Triangulation<1, 2>::max_adjacent_cells() const
13208 {
13209  return 2;
13210 }
13211 
13212 
13213 template <>
13214 unsigned int
13215 Triangulation<1, 3>::max_adjacent_cells() const
13216 {
13217  return 2;
13218 }
13219 
13220 
13221 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13222 unsigned int
13223 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::max_adjacent_cells() const
13224 {
13225  cell_iterator cell = begin(0),
13226  endc = (n_levels() > 1 ? begin(1) : cell_iterator(end()));
13227  // store the largest index of the
13228  // vertices used on level 0
13229  unsigned int max_vertex_index = 0;
13230  for (; cell != endc; ++cell)
13231  for (const unsigned int vertex : GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13232  if (cell->vertex_index(vertex) > max_vertex_index)
13233  max_vertex_index = cell->vertex_index(vertex);
13234 
13235  // store the number of times a cell
13236  // touches a vertex. An unsigned
13237  // int should suffice, even for
13238  // larger dimensions
13239  std::vector<unsigned short int> usage_count(max_vertex_index + 1, 0);
13240  // touch a vertex's usage count
13241  // every time we find an adjacent
13242  // element
13243  for (cell = begin(); cell != endc; ++cell)
13244  for (const unsigned int vertex : GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13245  ++usage_count[cell->vertex_index(vertex)];
13246 
13247  return std::max(GeometryInfo<dim>::vertices_per_cell,
13248  static_cast<unsigned int>(
13249  *std::max_element(usage_count.begin(), usage_count.end())));
13250 }
13251 
13252 
13253 
13254 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13255 types::subdomain_id
13256 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::locally_owned_subdomain() const
13257 {
13258  return numbers::invalid_subdomain_id;
13259 }
13260 
13261 
13262 
13263 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13264 Triangulation<dim, spacedim> &
13265 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::get_triangulation()
13266 {
13267  return *this;
13268 }
13269 
13270 
13271 
13272 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13273 const Triangulation<dim, spacedim> &
13274 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::get_triangulation() const
13275 {
13276  return *this;
13277 }
13278 
13279 
13280 
13281 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13282 void
13283 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::add_periodicity(
13284  const std::vector<GridTools::PeriodicFacePair<cell_iterator>>
13285  &periodicity_vector)
13286 {
13287  periodic_face_pairs_level_0.insert(periodic_face_pairs_level_0.end(),
13288  periodicity_vector.begin(),
13289  periodicity_vector.end());
13290 
13291  // Now initialize periodic_face_map
13292  update_periodic_face_map();
13293 }
13294 
13295 
13296 
13297 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13298 const typename std::map<
13299  std::pair<typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator, unsigned int>,
13300  std::pair<std::pair<typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator,
13301  unsigned int>,
13302  std::bitset<3>>> &
13303 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::get_periodic_face_map() const
13304 {
13305  return periodic_face_map;
13306 }
13307 
13308 
13309 
13310 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13311 void
13312 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::execute_coarsening_and_refinement()
13313 {
13314  // Call our version of prepare_coarsening_and_refinement() even if a derived
13315  // class like parallel::distributed::Triangulation overrides it. Their
13316  // function will be called in their execute_coarsening_and_refinement()
13317  // function. Even in a distributed computation our job here is to reconstruct
13318  // the local part of the mesh and as such checking our flags is enough.
13319  Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::prepare_coarsening_and_refinement();
13320 
13321  // verify a case with which we have had
13322  // some difficulty in the past (see the
13323  // deal.II/coarsening_* tests)
13324  if (smooth_grid & limit_level_difference_at_vertices)
13325  Assert(satisfies_level1_at_vertex_rule(*this) == true, ExcInternalError());
13326 
13327  // Inform all listeners about beginning of refinement.
13328  signals.pre_refinement();
13329 
13330  execute_coarsening();
13331 
13332  const DistortedCellList cells_with_distorted_children = execute_refinement();
13333 
13334  reset_cell_vertex_indices_cache();
13335 
13336  // verify a case with which we have had
13337  // some difficulty in the past (see the
13338  // deal.II/coarsening_* tests)
13339  if (smooth_grid & limit_level_difference_at_vertices)
13340  Assert(satisfies_level1_at_vertex_rule(*this) == true, ExcInternalError());
13341 
13342  // finally build up neighbor connectivity information, and set
13343  // active cell indices
13344  this->policy->update_neighbors(*this);
13345  reset_active_cell_indices();
13346 
13347  reset_global_cell_indices(); // TODO: better place?
13348 
13349  // Inform all listeners about end of refinement.
13350  signals.post_refinement();
13351 
13352  AssertThrow(cells_with_distorted_children.distorted_cells.size() == 0,
13353  cells_with_distorted_children);
13354 
13355  update_periodic_face_map();
13356 }
13357 
13358 
13359 
13360 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13361 void
13362 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::reset_active_cell_indices()
13363 {
13364  unsigned int active_cell_index = 0;
13365  for (raw_cell_iterator cell = begin_raw(); cell != end(); ++cell)
13366  if ((cell->used() == false) || cell->has_children())
13367  cell->set_active_cell_index(numbers::invalid_unsigned_int);
13368  else
13369  {
13370  cell->set_active_cell_index(active_cell_index);
13371  ++active_cell_index;
13372  }
13373 
13374  Assert(active_cell_index == n_active_cells(), ExcInternalError());
13375 }
13376 
13377 
13378 
13379 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13380 void
13381 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::reset_global_cell_indices()
13382 {
13383  {
13384  types::global_cell_index cell_index = 0;
13385  for (const auto &cell : active_cell_iterators())
13386  cell->set_global_active_cell_index(cell_index++);
13387  }
13388 
13389  for (unsigned int l = 0; l < levels.size(); ++l)
13390  {
13391  types::global_cell_index cell_index = 0;
13392  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators_on_level(l))
13393  cell->set_global_level_cell_index(cell_index++);
13394  }
13395 }
13396 
13397 
13398 
13399 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13400 void
13401 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::reset_cell_vertex_indices_cache()
13402 {
13403  for (unsigned int l = 0; l < levels.size(); ++l)
13404  {
13405  constexpr unsigned int max_vertices_per_cell = 1 << dim;
13406  std::vector<unsigned int> &cache = levels[l]->cell_vertex_indices_cache;
13407  cache.clear();
13408  cache.resize(levels[l]->refine_flags.size() * max_vertices_per_cell,
13409  numbers::invalid_unsigned_int);
13410  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators_on_level(l))
13411  {
13412  const unsigned int my_index = cell->index() * max_vertices_per_cell;
13413  for (const unsigned int i : cell->vertex_indices())
13414  cache[my_index + i] = internal::TriaAccessorImplementation::
13415  Implementation::vertex_index(*cell, i);
13416  }
13417  }
13418 }
13419 
13420 
13421 
13422 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13423 void
13424 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::update_periodic_face_map()
13425 {
13426  // first empty the currently stored objects
13427  periodic_face_map.clear();
13428 
13429  typename std::vector<
13430  GridTools::PeriodicFacePair<cell_iterator>>::const_iterator it;
13431  for (it = periodic_face_pairs_level_0.begin();
13432  it != periodic_face_pairs_level_0.end();
13433  ++it)
13434  {
13435  update_periodic_face_map_recursively<dim, spacedim>(it->cell[0],
13436  it->cell[1],
13437  it->face_idx[0],
13438  it->face_idx[1],
13439  it->orientation,
13440  periodic_face_map);
13441 
13442  // for the other way, we need to invert the orientation
13443  std::bitset<3> inverted_orientation;
13444  {
13445  bool orientation, flip, rotation;
13446  orientation = it->orientation[0];
13447  rotation = it->orientation[2];
13448  flip = orientation ? rotation ^ it->orientation[1] : it->orientation[1];
13449  inverted_orientation[0] = orientation;
13450  inverted_orientation[1] = flip;
13451  inverted_orientation[2] = rotation;
13452  }
13453  update_periodic_face_map_recursively<dim, spacedim>(it->cell[1],
13454  it->cell[0],
13455  it->face_idx[1],
13456  it->face_idx[0],
13457  inverted_orientation,
13458  periodic_face_map);
13459  }
13460 
13461  // check consistency
13462  typename std::map<std::pair<cell_iterator, unsigned int>,
13463  std::pair<std::pair<cell_iterator, unsigned int>,
13464  std::bitset<3>>>::const_iterator it_test;
13465  for (it_test = periodic_face_map.begin(); it_test != periodic_face_map.end();
13466  ++it_test)
13467  {
13468  const Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator cell_1 =
13469  it_test->first.first;
13470  const Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator cell_2 =
13471  it_test->second.first.first;
13472  if (cell_1->level() == cell_2->level())
13473  {
13474  // if both cells have the same neighbor, then the same pair
13475  // order swapped has to be in the map
13476  Assert(periodic_face_map[it_test->second.first].first ==
13477  it_test->first,
13478  ExcInternalError());
13479  }
13480  }
13481 }
13482 
13483 
13484 
13485 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13486 void
13487 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::update_reference_cells()
13488 {
13489  std::set<ReferenceCell> reference_cells_set;
13490  for (auto cell : active_cell_iterators())
13491  if (cell->is_locally_owned())
13492  reference_cells_set.insert(cell->reference_cell());
13493 
13494  std::vector<ReferenceCell> reference_cells(reference_cells_set.begin(),
13495  reference_cells_set.end());
13496 
13497  this->reference_cells = reference_cells;
13498 }
13499 
13500 
13501 
13502 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13503 const std::vector<ReferenceCell> &
13504 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::get_reference_cells() const
13505 {
13506  return this->reference_cells;
13507 }
13508 
13509 
13510 
13511 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13512 bool
13513 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::all_reference_cells_are_hyper_cube() const
13514 {
13515  Assert(this->reference_cells.size() > 0,
13516  ExcMessage("You can't ask about the kinds of reference "
13517  "cells used by this triangulation if the "
13518  "triangulation doesn't yet have any cells in it."));
13519  return (this->reference_cells.size() == 1 &&
13520  this->reference_cells[0] == ReferenceCells::get_hypercube<dim>());
13521 }
13522 
13523 
13524 
13525 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13526 void
13527 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::clear_despite_subscriptions()
13528 {
13529  levels.clear();
13530  faces.reset();
13531 
13532  vertices.clear();
13533  vertices_used.clear();
13534 
13535  manifold.clear();
13536 
13537  number_cache = internal::TriangulationImplementation::NumberCache<dim>();
13538 }
13539 
13540 
13541 
13542 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13543 typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::DistortedCellList
13544 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::execute_refinement()
13545 {
13546  const DistortedCellList cells_with_distorted_children =
13547  this->policy->execute_refinement(*this, check_for_distorted_cells);
13548 
13549 
13550 
13551  // re-compute number of lines
13552  internal::TriangulationImplementation::Implementation::compute_number_cache(
13553  *this, levels.size(), number_cache);
13554 
13555 #ifdef DEBUG
13556  for (const auto &level : levels)
13557  monitor_memory(level->cells, dim);
13558 
13559  // check whether really all refinement flags are reset (also of
13560  // previously non-active cells which we may not have touched. If the
13561  // refinement flag of a non-active cell is set, something went wrong
13562  // since the cell-accessors should have caught this)
13563  for (const auto &cell : this->cell_iterators())
13564  Assert(!cell->refine_flag_set(), ExcInternalError());
13565 #endif
13566 
13567  return cells_with_distorted_children;
13568 }
13569 
13570 
13571 
13572 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13573 void
13574 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::execute_coarsening()
13575 {
13576  // create a vector counting for each line how many cells contain
13577  // this line. in 3D, this is used later on to decide which lines can
13578  // be deleted after coarsening a cell. in other dimensions it will
13579  // be ignored
13580  std::vector<unsigned int> line_cell_count =
13581  count_cells_bounded_by_line(*this);
13582  std::vector<unsigned int> quad_cell_count =
13583  count_cells_bounded_by_quad(*this);
13584 
13585  // loop over all cells. Flag all cells of which all children are
13586  // flagged for coarsening and delete the childrens' flags. In
13587  // effect, only those cells are flagged of which originally all
13588  // children were flagged and for which all children are on the same
13589  // refinement level. For flagging, the user flags are used, to avoid
13590  // confusion and because non-active cells can't be flagged for
13591  // coarsening. Note that because of the effects of
13592  // @p{fix_coarsen_flags}, of a cell either all or no children must
13593  // be flagged for coarsening, so it is ok to only check the first
13594  // child
13595  clear_user_flags();
13596 
13597  for (const auto &cell : this->cell_iterators())
13598  if (!cell->is_active())
13599  if (cell->child(0)->coarsen_flag_set())
13600  {
13601  cell->set_user_flag();
13602  for (unsigned int child = 0; child < cell->n_children(); ++child)
13603  {
13604  Assert(cell->child(child)->coarsen_flag_set(),
13605  ExcInternalError());
13606  cell->child(child)->clear_coarsen_flag();
13607  }
13608  }
13609 
13610 
13611  // now do the actual coarsening step. Since the loop goes over used
13612  // cells we only need not worry about deleting some cells since the
13613  // ++operator will then just hop over them if we should hit one. Do
13614  // the loop in the reverse way since we may only delete some cells
13615  // if their neighbors have already been deleted (if the latter are
13616  // on a higher level for example)
13617  //
13618  // since we delete the *children* of cells, we can ignore cells
13619  // on the highest level, i.e., level must be less than or equal
13620  // to n_levels()-2.
13621  cell_iterator cell = begin(), endc = end();
13622  if (levels.size() >= 2)
13623  for (cell = last(); cell != endc; --cell)
13624  if (cell->level() <= static_cast<int>(levels.size() - 2) &&
13625  cell->user_flag_set())
13626  {
13627  // inform all listeners that cell coarsening is going to happen
13628  signals.pre_coarsening_on_cell(cell);
13629  // use a separate function, since this is dimension specific
13630  this->policy->delete_children(*this,
13631  cell,
13632  line_cell_count,
13633  quad_cell_count);
13634  }
13635 
13636  // re-compute number of lines and quads
13637  internal::TriangulationImplementation::Implementation::compute_number_cache(
13638  *this, levels.size(), number_cache);
13639 
13640  // in principle no user flags should be set any more at this point
13641 #if DEBUG
13642  for (cell = begin(); cell != endc; ++cell)
13643  Assert(cell->user_flag_set() == false, ExcInternalError());
13644 #endif
13645 }
13646 
13647 
13648 
13649 template <int dim, int spacedim>
13650 void
13651 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::fix_coarsen_flags()
13652 {
13653  // copy a piece of code from prepare_coarsening_and_refinement that
13654  // ensures that the level difference at vertices is limited if so
13655  // desired. we need this code here since at least in 1d we don't
13656  // call the dimension-independent version of
13657  // prepare_coarsening_and_refinement function. in 2d and 3d, having
13658  // this hunk here makes our lives a bit easier as well as it takes
13659  // care of these cases earlier than it would otherwise happen.
13660  //
13661  // the main difference to the code in p_c_and_r is that here we
13662  // absolutely have to make sure that we get things right, i.e. that
13663  // in particular we set flags right if
13664  // limit_level_difference_at_vertices is set. to do so we iterate
13665  // until the flags don't change any more
13666  std::vector<bool> previous_coarsen_flags(n_active_cells());
13667  save_coarsen_flags(previous_coarsen_flags);
13668 
13669  std::vector<int> vertex_level(vertices.size(), 0);
13670 
13671  bool continue_iterating = true;
13672 
13673  do
13674  {
13675  if (smooth_grid & limit_level_difference_at_vertices)
13676  {
13677  Assert(!anisotropic_refinement,
13678  ExcMessage("In case of anisotropic refinement the "
13679  "limit_level_difference_at_vertices flag for "
13680  "mesh smoothing must not be set!"));
13681 
13682  // store highest level one of the cells adjacent to a vertex
13683  // belongs to
13684  std::fill(vertex_level.begin(), vertex_level.end(), 0);
13685  for (const auto &cell : this->active_cell_iterators())
13686  {
13687  if (cell->refine_flag_set())
13688  for (const unsigned int vertex :
13689  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13690  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
13691  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
13692  cell->level() + 1);
13693  else if (!cell->coarsen_flag_set())
13694  for (const unsigned int vertex :
13695  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13696  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
13697  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
13698  cell->level());
13699  else
13700  {
13701  // if coarsen flag is set then tentatively assume
13702  // that the cell will be coarsened. this isn't
13703  // always true (the coarsen flag could be removed
13704  // again) and so we may make an error here. we try
13705  // to correct this by iterating over the entire
13706  // process until we are converged
13707  Assert(cell->coarsen_flag_set(), ExcInternalError());
13708  for (const unsigned int vertex :
13709  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13710  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
13711  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
13712  cell->level() - 1);
13713  }
13714  }
13715 
13716 
13717  // loop over all cells in reverse order. do so because we
13718  // can then update the vertex levels on the adjacent
13719  // vertices and maybe already flag additional cells in this
13720  // loop
13721  //
13722  // note that not only may we have to add additional
13723  // refinement flags, but we will also have to remove
13724  // coarsening flags on cells adjacent to vertices that will
13725  // see refinement
13726  active_cell_iterator cell = begin_active(), endc = end();
13727  for (cell = last_active(); cell != endc; --cell)
13728  if (cell->refine_flag_set() == false)
13729  {
13730  for (const unsigned int vertex :
13731  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13732  if (vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] >=
13733  cell->level() + 1)
13734  {
13735  // remove coarsen flag...
13736  cell->clear_coarsen_flag();
13737 
13738  // ...and if necessary also refine the current
13739  // cell, at the same time updating the level
13740  // information about vertices
13741  if (vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] >
13742  cell->level() + 1)
13743  {
13744  cell->set_refine_flag();
13745 
13746  for (const unsigned int v :
13747  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
13748  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(v)] =
13749  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(v)],
13750  cell->level() + 1);
13751  }
13752 
13753  // continue and see whether we may, for example,
13754  // go into the inner 'if' above based on a
13755  // different vertex
13756  }
13757  }
13758  }
13759 
13760  // loop over all cells. Flag all cells of which all children are
13761  // flagged for coarsening and delete the childrens' flags. Also
13762  // delete all flags of cells for which not all children of a
13763  // cell are flagged. In effect, only those cells are flagged of
13764  // which originally all children were flagged and for which all
13765  // children are on the same refinement level. For flagging, the
13766  // user flags are used, to avoid confusion and because
13767  // non-active cells can't be flagged for coarsening
13768  //
13769  // In effect, all coarsen flags are turned into user flags of
13770  // the mother cell if coarsening is possible or deleted
13771  // otherwise.
13772  clear_user_flags();
13773  // Coarsen flags of cells with no mother cell, i.e. on the
13774  // coarsest level are deleted explicitly.
13775  for (const auto &acell : this->active_cell_iterators_on_level(0))
13776  acell->clear_coarsen_flag();
13777 
13778  for (const auto &cell : this->cell_iterators())
13779  {
13780  // nothing to do if we are already on the finest level
13781  if (cell->is_active())
13782  continue;
13783 
13784  const unsigned int n_children = cell->n_children();
13785  unsigned int flagged_children = 0;
13786  for (unsigned int child = 0; child < n_children; ++child)
13787  if (cell->child(child)->is_active() &&
13788  cell->child(child)->coarsen_flag_set())
13789  {
13790  ++flagged_children;
13791  // clear flag since we don't need it anymore
13792  cell->child(child)->clear_coarsen_flag();
13793  }
13794 
13795  // flag this cell for coarsening if all children were
13796  // flagged
13797  if (flagged_children == n_children)
13798  cell->set_user_flag();
13799  }
13800 
13801  // in principle no coarsen flags should be set any more at this
13802  // point
13803 #if DEBUG
13804  for (auto &cell : this->cell_iterators())
13805  Assert(cell->coarsen_flag_set() == false, ExcInternalError());
13806 #endif
13807 
13808  // now loop over all cells which have the user flag set. their
13809  // children were flagged for coarsening. set the coarsen flag
13810  // again if we are sure that none of the neighbors of these
13811  // children are refined, or will be refined, since then we would
13812  // get a two-level jump in refinement. on the other hand, if one
13813  // of the children's neighbors has their user flag set, then we
13814  // know that its children will go away by coarsening, and we
13815  // will be ok.
13816  //
13817  // note on the other hand that we do allow level-2 jumps in
13818  // refinement between neighbors in 1d, so this whole procedure
13819  // is only necessary if we are not in 1d
13820  //
13821  // since we remove some coarsening/user flags in the process, we
13822  // have to work from the finest level to the coarsest one, since
13823  // we occasionally inspect user flags of cells on finer levels
13824  // and need to be sure that these flags are final
13825  cell_iterator cell = begin(), endc = end();
13826  for (cell = last(); cell != endc; --cell)
13827  if (cell->user_flag_set())
13828  // if allowed: flag the
13829  // children for coarsening
13830  if (this->policy->coarsening_allowed(cell))
13831  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < cell->n_children(); ++c)
13832  {
13833  Assert(cell->child(c)->refine_flag_set() == false,
13834  ExcInternalError());
13835 
13836  cell->child(c)->set_coarsen_flag();
13837  }
13838 
13839  // clear all user flags again, now that we don't need them any
13840  // more
13841  clear_user_flags();
13842 
13843 
13844  // now see if anything has changed in the last iteration of this
13845  // function
13846  std::vector<bool> current_coarsen_flags(n_active_cells());
13847  save_coarsen_flags(current_coarsen_flags);
13848 
13849  continue_iterating = (current_coarsen_flags != previous_coarsen_flags);
13850  previous_coarsen_flags = current_coarsen_flags;
13851  }
13852  while (continue_iterating == true);
13853 }
13854 
13855 
13856 // TODO: merge the following 3 functions since they are the same
13857 template <>
13858 bool
13859 Triangulation<1, 1>::prepare_coarsening_and_refinement()
13860 {
13861  // save the flags to determine whether something was changed in the
13862  // course of this function
13863  std::vector<bool> flags_before;
13864  save_coarsen_flags(flags_before);
13865 
13866  // do nothing in 1d, except setting the coarsening flags correctly
13867  fix_coarsen_flags();
13868 
13869  std::vector<bool> flags_after;
13870  save_coarsen_flags(flags_after);
13871 
13872  return (flags_before != flags_after);
13873 }
13874 
13875 
13876 template <>
13877 bool
13878 Triangulation<1, 2>::prepare_coarsening_and_refinement()
13879 {
13880  // save the flags to determine whether something was changed in the
13881  // course of this function
13882  std::vector<bool> flags_before;
13883  save_coarsen_flags(flags_before);
13884 
13885  // do nothing in 1d, except setting the coarsening flags correctly
13886  fix_coarsen_flags();
13887 
13888  std::vector<bool> flags_after;
13889  save_coarsen_flags(flags_after);
13890 
13891  return (flags_before != flags_after);
13892 }
13893 
13894 
13895 template <>
13896 bool
13897 Triangulation<1, 3>::prepare_coarsening_and_refinement()
13898 {
13899  // save the flags to determine whether something was changed in the
13900  // course of this function
13901  std::vector<bool> flags_before;
13902  save_coarsen_flags(flags_before);
13903 
13904  // do nothing in 1d, except setting the coarsening flags correctly
13905  fix_coarsen_flags();
13906 
13907  std::vector<bool> flags_after;
13908  save_coarsen_flags(flags_after);
13909 
13910  return (flags_before != flags_after);
13911 }
13912 
13913 
13914 
13915 namespace
13916 {
13917  // check if the given @param cell marked for coarsening would
13918  // produce an unrefined island. To break up long chains of these
13919  // cells we recursively check our neighbors in case we change this
13920  // cell. This reduces the number of outer iterations dramatically.
13921  template <int dim, int spacedim>
13922  void
13923  possibly_do_not_produce_unrefined_islands(
13924  const typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator &cell)
13925  {
13926  Assert(cell->has_children(), ExcInternalError());
13927 
13928  unsigned int n_neighbors = 0;
13929  // count all neighbors that will be refined along the face of our
13930  // cell after the next step
13931  unsigned int count = 0;
13932  for (unsigned int n : GeometryInfo<dim>::face_indices())
13933  {
13934  const typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator neighbor =
13935  cell->neighbor(n);
13936  if (neighbor.state() == IteratorState::valid)
13937  {
13938  ++n_neighbors;
13939  if (face_will_be_refined_by_neighbor(cell, n))
13940  ++count;
13941  }
13942  }
13943  // clear coarsen flags if either all existing neighbors will be
13944  // refined or all but one will be and the cell is in the interior
13945  // of the domain
13946  if (count == n_neighbors ||
13947  (count >= n_neighbors - 1 &&
13948  n_neighbors == GeometryInfo<dim>::faces_per_cell))
13949  {
13950  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < cell->n_children(); ++c)
13951  cell->child(c)->clear_coarsen_flag();
13952 
13953  for (const unsigned int face : GeometryInfo<dim>::face_indices())
13954  if (!cell->at_boundary(face) &&
13955  (!cell->neighbor(face)->is_active()) &&
13956  (cell_will_be_coarsened(cell->neighbor(face))))
13957  possibly_do_not_produce_unrefined_islands<dim, spacedim>(
13958  cell->neighbor(face));
13959  }
13960  }
13961 
13962 
13963  // see if the current cell needs to be refined to avoid unrefined
13964  // islands.
13965  //
13966  // there are sometimes chains of cells that induce refinement of
13967  // each other. to avoid running the loop in
13968  // prepare_coarsening_and_refinement over and over again for each
13969  // one of them, at least for the isotropic refinement case we seek
13970  // to flag neighboring elements as well as necessary. this takes
13971  // care of (slightly pathological) cases like
13972  // deal.II/mesh_smoothing_03
13973  template <int dim, int spacedim>
13974  void
13975  possibly_refine_unrefined_island(
13976  const typename Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::cell_iterator &cell,
13977  const bool allow_anisotropic_smoothing)
13978  {
13979  Assert(cell->is_active(), ExcInternalError());
13980  Assert(cell->refine_flag_set() == false, ExcInternalError());
13981 
13982 
13983  // now we provide two algorithms. the first one is the standard
13984  // one, coming from the time, where only isotropic refinement was
13985  // possible. it simply counts the neighbors that are or will be
13986  // refined and compares to the number of other ones. the second
13987  // one does this check independently for each direction: if all
13988  // neighbors in one direction (normally two, at the boundary only
13989  // one) are refined, the current cell is flagged to be refined in
13990  // an according direction.
13991 
13992  if (allow_anisotropic_smoothing == false)
13993  {
13994  // use first algorithm
13995  unsigned int refined_neighbors = 0, unrefined_neighbors = 0;
13996  for (const unsigned int face : GeometryInfo<dim>::face_indices())
13997  if (!cell->at_boundary(face))
13998  {
13999  if (face_will_be_refined_by_neighbor(cell, face))
14000  ++refined_neighbors;
14001  else
14002  ++unrefined_neighbors;
14003  }
14004 
14005  if (unrefined_neighbors < refined_neighbors)
14006  {
14007  cell->clear_coarsen_flag();
14008  cell->set_refine_flag();
14009 
14010  // ok, so now we have flagged this cell. if we know that
14011  // there were any unrefined neighbors at all, see if any
14012  // of those will have to be refined as well
14013  if (unrefined_neighbors > 0)
14014  for (const unsigned int face : GeometryInfo<dim>::face_indices())
14015  if (!cell->at_boundary(face) &&
14016  (face_will_be_refined_by_neighbor(cell, face) == false) &&
14017  (cell->neighbor(face)->has_children() == false) &&
14018  (cell->neighbor(face)->refine_flag_set() == false))
14019  possibly_refine_unrefined_island<dim, spacedim>(
14020  cell->neighbor(face), allow_anisotropic_smoothing);
14021  }
14022  }
14023  else
14024  {
14025  // variable to store the cell refine case needed to fulfill
14026  // all smoothing requirements
14027  RefinementCase<dim> smoothing_cell_refinement_case =
14028  RefinementCase<dim>::no_refinement;
14029 
14030  // use second algorithm, do the check individually for each
14031  // direction
14032  for (unsigned int face_pair = 0;
14033  face_pair < GeometryInfo<dim>::faces_per_cell / 2;
14034  ++face_pair)
14035  {
14036  // variable to store the cell refine case needed to refine
14037  // at the current face pair in the same way as the
14038  // neighbors do...
14039  RefinementCase<dim> directional_cell_refinement_case =
14040  RefinementCase<dim>::isotropic_refinement;
14041 
14042  for (unsigned int face_index = 0; face_index < 2; ++face_index)
14043  {
14044  unsigned int face = 2 * face_pair + face_index;
14045  // variable to store the refine case (to come) of the
14046  // face under consideration
14047  RefinementCase<dim - 1> expected_face_ref_case =
14048  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::no_refinement;
14049 
14050  if (cell->neighbor(face).state() == IteratorState::valid)
14051  face_will_be_refined_by_neighbor<dim, spacedim>(
14052  cell, face, expected_face_ref_case);
14053  // now extract which refine case would be necessary to
14054  // achieve the same face refinement. set the
14055  // intersection with other requirements for the same
14056  // direction.
14057 
14058  // note: using the intersection is not an obvious
14059  // decision, we could also argue that it is more
14060  // natural to use the union. however, intersection is
14061  // the less aggressive tactic and favours a smaller
14062  // number of refined cells over an intensive
14063  // smoothing. this way we try not to lose too much of
14064  // the effort we put in anisotropic refinement
14065  // indicators due to overly aggressive smoothing...
14066  directional_cell_refinement_case =
14067  (directional_cell_refinement_case &
14068  GeometryInfo<dim>::
14069  min_cell_refinement_case_for_face_refinement(
14070  expected_face_ref_case,
14071  face,
14072  cell->face_orientation(face),
14073  cell->face_flip(face),
14074  cell->face_rotation(face)));
14075  } // for both face indices
14076  // if both requirements sum up to something useful, add
14077  // this to the refine case for smoothing. note: if
14078  // directional_cell_refinement_case is isotropic still,
14079  // then something went wrong...
14080  Assert(directional_cell_refinement_case <
14081  RefinementCase<dim>::isotropic_refinement,
14082  ExcInternalError());
14083  smoothing_cell_refinement_case =
14084  smoothing_cell_refinement_case | directional_cell_refinement_case;
14085  } // for all face_pairs
14086  // no we collected contributions from all directions. combine
14087  // the new flags with the existing refine case, but only if
14088  // smoothing is required
14089  if (smoothing_cell_refinement_case)
14090  {
14091  cell->clear_coarsen_flag();
14092  cell->set_refine_flag(cell->refine_flag_set() |
14093  smoothing_cell_refinement_case);
14094  }
14095  }
14096  }
14097 } // namespace
14098 
14099 
14100 template <int dim, int spacedim>
14101 bool
14102 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::prepare_coarsening_and_refinement()
14103 {
14104  // save the flags to determine whether something was changed in the
14105  // course of this function
14106  std::vector<bool> flags_before[2];
14107  save_coarsen_flags(flags_before[0]);
14108  save_refine_flags(flags_before[1]);
14109 
14110  // save the flags at the outset of each loop. we do so in order to
14111  // find out whether something was changed in the present loop, in
14112  // which case we would have to re-run the loop. the other
14113  // possibility to find this out would be to set a flag
14114  // @p{something_changed} to true each time we change something.
14115  // however, sometimes one change in one of the parts of the loop is
14116  // undone by another one, so we might end up in an endless loop. we
14117  // could be tempted to break this loop at an arbitrary number of
14118  // runs, but that would not be a clean solution, since we would
14119  // either have to 1/ break the loop too early, in which case the
14120  // promise that a second call to this function immediately after the
14121  // first one does not change anything, would be broken, or 2/ we do
14122  // as many loops as there are levels. we know that information is
14123  // transported over one level in each run of the loop, so this is
14124  // enough. Unfortunately, each loop is rather expensive, so we chose
14125  // the way presented here
14126  std::vector<bool> flags_before_loop[2] = {flags_before[0], flags_before[1]};
14127 
14128  // now for what is done in each loop: we have to fulfill several
14129  // tasks at the same time, namely several mesh smoothing algorithms
14130  // and mesh regularization, by which we mean that the next mesh
14131  // fulfills several requirements such as no double refinement at
14132  // each face or line, etc.
14133  //
14134  // since doing these things at once seems almost impossible (in the
14135  // first year of this library, they were done in two functions, one
14136  // for refinement and one for coarsening, and most things within
14137  // these were done at once, so the code was rather impossible to
14138  // join into this, only, function), we do them one after each
14139  // other. the order in which we do them is such that the important
14140  // tasks, namely regularization, are done last and the least
14141  // important things are done the first. the following order is
14142  // chosen:
14143  //
14144  // 0/ Only if coarsest_level_1 or patch_level_1 is set: clear all
14145  // coarsen flags on level 1 to avoid level 0 cells being created
14146  // by coarsening. As coarsen flags will never be added, this can
14147  // be done once and for all before the actual loop starts.
14148  //
14149  // 1/ do not coarsen a cell if 'most of the neighbors' will be
14150  // refined after the step. This is to prevent occurrence of
14151  // unrefined islands.
14152  //
14153  // 2/ eliminate refined islands in the interior and at the
14154  // boundary. since they don't do much harm besides increasing the
14155  // number of degrees of freedom, doing this has a rather low
14156  // priority.
14157  //
14158  // 3/ limit the level difference of neighboring cells at each
14159  // vertex.
14160  //
14161  // 4/ eliminate unrefined islands. this has higher priority since
14162  // this diminishes the approximation properties not only of the
14163  // unrefined island, but also of the surrounding patch.
14164  //
14165  // 5/ ensure patch level 1. Then the triangulation consists of
14166  // patches, i.e. of cells that are refined once. It follows that
14167  // if at least one of the children of a cell is or will be
14168  // refined than all children need to be refined. This step only
14169  // sets refinement flags and does not set coarsening flags. If
14170  // the patch_level_1 flag is set, then
14171  // eliminate_unrefined_islands, eliminate_refined_inner_islands
14172  // and eliminate_refined_boundary_islands will be fulfilled
14173  // automatically and do not need to be enforced separately.
14174  //
14175  // 6/ take care of the requirement that no double refinement is done
14176  // at each face
14177  //
14178  // 7/ take care that no double refinement is done at each line in 3d
14179  // or higher dimensions.
14180  //
14181  // 8/ make sure that all children of each cell are either flagged
14182  // for coarsening or none of the children is
14183  //
14184  // For some of these steps, it is known that they interact. Namely,
14185  // it is not possible to guarantee that after step 6 another step 5
14186  // would have no effect; the same holds for the opposite order and
14187  // also when taking into account step 7. however, it is important to
14188  // guarantee that step five or six do not undo something that step 5
14189  // did, and step 7 not something of step 6, otherwise the
14190  // requirements will not be satisfied even if the loop
14191  // terminates. this is accomplished by the fact that steps 5 and 6
14192  // only *add* refinement flags and delete coarsening flags
14193  // (therefore, step 6 can't undo something that step 4 already did),
14194  // and step 7 only deletes coarsening flags, never adds some. step 7
14195  // needs also take care that it won't tag cells for refinement for
14196  // which some neighbors are more refined or will be refined.
14197 
14199  // STEP 0:
14200  // Only if coarsest_level_1 or patch_level_1 is set: clear all
14201  // coarsen flags on level 1 to avoid level 0 cells being created
14202  // by coarsening.
14203  if (((smooth_grid & coarsest_level_1) || (smooth_grid & patch_level_1)) &&
14204  n_levels() >= 2)
14205  {
14206  for (const auto &cell : active_cell_iterators_on_level(1))
14207  cell->clear_coarsen_flag();
14208  }
14209 
14210  bool mesh_changed_in_this_loop = false;
14211  do
14212  {
14214  // STEP 1:
14215  // do not coarsen a cell if 'most of the neighbors' will be
14216  // refined after the step. This is to prevent the occurrence
14217  // of unrefined islands. If patch_level_1 is set, this will
14218  // be automatically fulfilled.
14219  if (smooth_grid & do_not_produce_unrefined_islands &&
14220  !(smooth_grid & patch_level_1))
14221  {
14222  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators())
14223  {
14224  // only do something if this
14225  // cell will be coarsened
14226  if (!cell->is_active() && cell_will_be_coarsened(cell))
14227  possibly_do_not_produce_unrefined_islands<dim, spacedim>(cell);
14228  }
14229  }
14230 
14231 
14233  // STEP 2:
14234  // eliminate refined islands in the interior and at the
14235  // boundary. since they don't do much harm besides increasing
14236  // the number of degrees of freedom, doing this has a rather
14237  // low priority. If patch_level_1 is set, this will be
14238  // automatically fulfilled.
14239  //
14240  // there is one corner case to consider: if this is a
14241  // distributed triangulation, there may be refined islands on
14242  // the boundary of which we own only part (e.g. a single cell
14243  // in the corner of a domain). the rest of the island is
14244  // ghost cells and it *looks* like the area around it
14245  // (artificial cells) are coarser but this is only because
14246  // they may actually be equally fine on other
14247  // processors. it's hard to detect this case but we can do
14248  // the following: only set coarsen flags to remove this
14249  // refined island if all cells we want to set flags on are
14250  // locally owned
14251  if (smooth_grid & (eliminate_refined_inner_islands |
14252  eliminate_refined_boundary_islands) &&
14253  !(smooth_grid & patch_level_1))
14254  {
14255  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators())
14256  if (!cell->is_active() ||
14257  (cell->is_active() && cell->refine_flag_set() &&
14258  cell->is_locally_owned()))
14259  {
14260  // check whether all children are active, i.e. not
14261  // refined themselves. This is a precondition that the
14262  // children may be coarsened away. If the cell is only
14263  // flagged for refinement, then all future children
14264  // will be active
14265  bool all_children_active = true;
14266  if (!cell->is_active())
14267  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < cell->n_children(); ++c)
14268  if (!cell->child(c)->is_active() ||
14269  cell->child(c)->is_ghost() ||
14270  cell->child(c)->is_artificial())
14271  {
14272  all_children_active = false;
14273  break;
14274  }
14275 
14276  if (all_children_active)
14277  {
14278  // count number of refined and unrefined neighbors
14279  // of cell. neighbors on lower levels are counted
14280  // as unrefined since they can only get to the
14281  // same level as this cell by the next refinement
14282  // cycle
14283  unsigned int unrefined_neighbors = 0, total_neighbors = 0;
14284 
14285  // Keep track if this cell is at a periodic
14286  // boundary or not. TODO: We do not currently run
14287  // the algorithm for inner islands at a periodic
14288  // boundary (remains to be implemented), but we
14289  // also don't want to consider them
14290  // boundary_island cells as this can interfere
14291  // with 2:1 refinement across periodic faces.
14292  // Instead: just ignore those cells for this
14293  // smoothing operation below.
14294  bool at_periodic_boundary = false;
14295 
14296  for (const unsigned int n :
14297  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_indices())
14298  {
14299  const cell_iterator neighbor = cell->neighbor(n);
14300  if (neighbor.state() == IteratorState::valid)
14301  {
14302  ++total_neighbors;
14303 
14304  if (!face_will_be_refined_by_neighbor(cell, n))
14305  ++unrefined_neighbors;
14306  }
14307  else if (cell->has_periodic_neighbor(n))
14308  {
14309  ++total_neighbors;
14310  at_periodic_boundary = true;
14311  }
14312  }
14313 
14314  // if all neighbors unrefined: mark this cell for
14315  // coarsening or don't refine if marked for that
14316  //
14317  // also do the distinction between the two
14318  // versions of the eliminate_refined_*_islands
14319  // flag
14320  //
14321  // the last check is whether there are any
14322  // neighbors at all. if not so, then we are (e.g.)
14323  // on the coarsest grid with one cell, for which,
14324  // of course, we do not remove the refine flag.
14325  if ((unrefined_neighbors == total_neighbors) &&
14326  ((!cell->at_boundary() &&
14327  (smooth_grid & eliminate_refined_inner_islands)) ||
14328  (cell->at_boundary() && !at_periodic_boundary &&
14329  (smooth_grid &
14330  eliminate_refined_boundary_islands))) &&
14331  (total_neighbors != 0))
14332  {
14333  if (!cell->is_active())
14334  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < cell->n_children(); ++c)
14335  {
14336  cell->child(c)->clear_refine_flag();
14337  cell->child(c)->set_coarsen_flag();
14338  }
14339  else
14340  cell->clear_refine_flag();
14341  }
14342  }
14343  }
14344  }
14345 
14347  // STEP 3:
14348  // limit the level difference of neighboring cells at each
14349  // vertex.
14350  //
14351  // in case of anisotropic refinement this does not make
14352  // sense. as soon as one cell is anisotropically refined, an
14353  // Assertion is thrown. therefore we can ignore this problem
14354  // later on
14355  if (smooth_grid & limit_level_difference_at_vertices)
14356  {
14357  Assert(!anisotropic_refinement,
14358  ExcMessage("In case of anisotropic refinement the "
14359  "limit_level_difference_at_vertices flag for "
14360  "mesh smoothing must not be set!"));
14361 
14362  // store highest level one of the cells adjacent to a vertex
14363  // belongs to
14364  std::vector<int> vertex_level(vertices.size(), 0);
14365  for (const auto &cell : active_cell_iterators())
14366  {
14367  if (cell->refine_flag_set())
14368  for (const unsigned int vertex :
14369  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
14370  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
14371  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
14372  cell->level() + 1);
14373  else if (!cell->coarsen_flag_set())
14374  for (const unsigned int vertex :
14375  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
14376  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
14377  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
14378  cell->level());
14379  else
14380  {
14381  // if coarsen flag is set then tentatively assume
14382  // that the cell will be coarsened. this isn't
14383  // always true (the coarsen flag could be removed
14384  // again) and so we may make an error here
14385  Assert(cell->coarsen_flag_set(), ExcInternalError());
14386  for (const unsigned int vertex :
14387  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
14388  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] =
14389  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)],
14390  cell->level() - 1);
14391  }
14392  }
14393 
14394 
14395  // loop over all cells in reverse order. do so because we
14396  // can then update the vertex levels on the adjacent
14397  // vertices and maybe already flag additional cells in this
14398  // loop
14399  //
14400  // note that not only may we have to add additional
14401  // refinement flags, but we will also have to remove
14402  // coarsening flags on cells adjacent to vertices that will
14403  // see refinement
14404  for (active_cell_iterator cell = last_active(); cell != end(); --cell)
14405  if (cell->refine_flag_set() == false)
14406  {
14407  for (const unsigned int vertex :
14408  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
14409  if (vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] >=
14410  cell->level() + 1)
14411  {
14412  // remove coarsen flag...
14413  cell->clear_coarsen_flag();
14414 
14415  // ...and if necessary also refine the current
14416  // cell, at the same time updating the level
14417  // information about vertices
14418  if (vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(vertex)] >
14419  cell->level() + 1)
14420  {
14421  cell->set_refine_flag();
14422 
14423  for (const unsigned int v :
14424  GeometryInfo<dim>::vertex_indices())
14425  vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(v)] =
14426  std::max(vertex_level[cell->vertex_index(v)],
14427  cell->level() + 1);
14428  }
14429 
14430  // continue and see whether we may, for example,
14431  // go into the inner'if'
14432  // above based on a
14433  // different vertex
14434  }
14435  }
14436  }
14437 
14439  // STEP 4:
14440  // eliminate unrefined islands. this has higher priority
14441  // since this diminishes the approximation properties not
14442  // only of the unrefined island, but also of the surrounding
14443  // patch.
14444  //
14445  // do the loop from finest to coarsest cells since we may
14446  // trigger a cascade by marking cells for refinement which
14447  // may trigger more cells further down below
14448  if (smooth_grid & eliminate_unrefined_islands)
14449  {
14450  for (active_cell_iterator cell = last_active(); cell != end(); --cell)
14451  // only do something if cell is not already flagged for
14452  // (isotropic) refinement
14453  if (cell->refine_flag_set() !=
14454  RefinementCase<dim>::isotropic_refinement)
14455  possibly_refine_unrefined_island<dim, spacedim>(
14456  cell, (smooth_grid & allow_anisotropic_smoothing) != 0);
14457  }
14458 
14460  // STEP 5:
14461  // ensure patch level 1.
14462  //
14463  // Introduce some terminology:
14464  // - a cell that is refined
14465  // once is a patch of
14466  // level 1 simply called patch.
14467  // - a cell that is globally
14468  // refined twice is called
14469  // a patch of level 2.
14470  // - patch level n says that
14471  // the triangulation consists
14472  // of patches of level n.
14473  // This makes sense only
14474  // if the grid is already at
14475  // least n times globally
14476  // refined.
14477  //
14478  // E.g. from patch level 1 follows: if at least one of the
14479  // children of a cell is or will be refined than enforce all
14480  // children to be refined.
14481 
14482  // This step 4 only sets refinement flags and does not set
14483  // coarsening flags.
14484  if (smooth_grid & patch_level_1)
14485  {
14486  // An important assumption (A) is that before calling this
14487  // function the grid was already of patch level 1.
14488 
14489  // loop over all cells whose children are all active. (By
14490  // assumption (A) either all or none of the children are
14491  // active). If the refine flag of at least one of the
14492  // children is set then set_refine_flag and
14493  // clear_coarsen_flag of all children.
14494  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators())
14495  if (!cell->is_active())
14496  {
14497  // ensure the invariant. we can then check whether all
14498  // of its children are further refined or not by
14499  // simply looking at the first child
14500  Assert(cell_is_patch_level_1(cell), ExcInternalError());
14501  if (cell->child(0)->has_children() == true)
14502  continue;
14503 
14504  // cell is found to be a patch. combine the refine
14505  // cases of all children
14506  RefinementCase<dim> combined_ref_case =
14507  RefinementCase<dim>::no_refinement;
14508  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < cell->n_children(); ++i)
14509  combined_ref_case =
14510  combined_ref_case | cell->child(i)->refine_flag_set();
14511  if (combined_ref_case != RefinementCase<dim>::no_refinement)
14512  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < cell->n_children(); ++i)
14513  {
14514  cell_iterator child = cell->child(i);
14515 
14516  child->clear_coarsen_flag();
14517  child->set_refine_flag(combined_ref_case);
14518  }
14519  }
14520 
14521  // The code above dealt with the case where we may get a
14522  // non-patch_level_1 mesh from refinement. Now also deal
14523  // with the case where we could get such a mesh by
14524  // coarsening. Coarsen the children (and remove the
14525  // grandchildren) only if all cell->grandchild(i)
14526  // ->coarsen_flag_set() are set.
14527  //
14528  // for a case where this is a bit tricky, take a look at the
14529  // mesh_smoothing_0[12] testcases
14530  for (const auto &cell : cell_iterators())
14531  {
14532  // check if this cell has active grandchildren. note
14533  // that we know that it is patch_level_1, i.e. if one of
14534  // its children is active then so are all, and it isn't
14535  // going to have any grandchildren at all:
14536  if (cell->is_active() || cell->child(0)->is_active())
14537  continue;
14538 
14539  // cell is not active, and so are none of its
14540  // children. check the grandchildren. note that the
14541  // children are also patch_level_1, and so we only ever
14542  // need to check their first child
14543  const unsigned int n_children = cell->n_children();
14544  bool has_active_grandchildren = false;
14545 
14546  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < n_children; ++i)
14547  if (cell->child(i)->child(0)->is_active())
14548  {
14549  has_active_grandchildren = true;
14550  break;
14551  }
14552 
14553  if (has_active_grandchildren == false)
14554  continue;
14555 
14556 
14557  // ok, there are active grandchildren. see if either all
14558  // or none of them are flagged for coarsening
14559  unsigned int n_grandchildren = 0;
14560 
14561  // count all coarsen flags of the grandchildren.
14562  unsigned int n_coarsen_flags = 0;
14563 
14564  // cell is not a patch (of level 1) as it has a
14565  // grandchild. Is cell a patch of level 2?? Therefore:
14566  // find out whether all cell->child(i) are patches
14567  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < n_children; ++c)
14568  {
14569  // get at the child. by assumption (A), and the
14570  // check by which we got here, the child is not
14571  // active
14572  cell_iterator child = cell->child(c);
14573 
14574  const unsigned int nn_children = child->n_children();
14575  n_grandchildren += nn_children;
14576 
14577  // if child is found to be a patch of active cells
14578  // itself, then add up how many of its children are
14579  // supposed to be coarsened
14580  if (child->child(0)->is_active())
14581  for (unsigned int cc = 0; cc < nn_children; ++cc)
14582  if (child->child(cc)->coarsen_flag_set())
14583  ++n_coarsen_flags;
14584  }
14585 
14586  // if not all grandchildren are supposed to be coarsened
14587  // (e.g. because some simply don't have the flag set, or
14588  // because they are not active and therefore cannot
14589  // carry the flag), then remove the coarsen flag from
14590  // all of the active grandchildren. note that there may
14591  // be coarsen flags on the grandgrandchildren -- we
14592  // don't clear them here, but we'll get to them in later
14593  // iterations if necessary
14594  //
14595  // there is nothing we have to do if no coarsen flags
14596  // have been set at all
14597  if ((n_coarsen_flags != n_grandchildren) && (n_coarsen_flags > 0))
14598  for (unsigned int c = 0; c < n_children; ++c)
14599  {
14600  const cell_iterator child = cell->child(c);
14601  if (child->child(0)->is_active())
14602  for (unsigned int cc = 0; cc < child->n_children(); ++cc)
14603  child->child(cc)->clear_coarsen_flag();
14604  }
14605  }
14606  }
14607 
14609  //
14610  // at the boundary we could end up with cells with negative
14611  // volume or at least with a part, that is negative, if the
14612  // cell is refined anisotropically. we have to check, whether
14613  // that can happen
14614  this->policy->prevent_distorted_boundary_cells(*this);
14615 
14617  // STEP 6:
14618  // take care of the requirement that no
14619  // double refinement is done at each face
14620  //
14621  // in case of anisotropic refinement it is only likely, but
14622  // not sure, that the cells, which are more refined along a
14623  // certain face common to two cells are on a higher
14624  // level. therefore we cannot be sure, that the requirement
14625  // of no double refinement is fulfilled after a single pass
14626  // of the following actions. We could just wait for the next
14627  // global loop. when this function terminates, the
14628  // requirement will be fulfilled. However, it might be faster
14629  // to insert an inner loop here.
14630  bool changed = true;
14631  while (changed)
14632  {
14633  changed = false;
14634  active_cell_iterator cell = last_active(), endc = end();
14635 
14636  for (; cell != endc; --cell)
14637  if (cell->refine_flag_set())
14638  {
14639  // loop over neighbors of cell
14640  for (const auto i : cell->face_indices())
14641  {
14642  // only do something if the face is not at the
14643  // boundary and if the face will be refined with
14644  // the RefineCase currently flagged for
14645  const bool has_periodic_neighbor =
14646  cell->has_periodic_neighbor(i);
14647  const bool has_neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor =
14648  !cell->at_boundary(i) || has_periodic_neighbor;
14649  if (has_neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor &&
14650  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
14651  cell->refine_flag_set(), i) !=
14652  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::no_refinement)
14653  {
14654  // 1) if the neighbor has children: nothing to
14655  // worry about. 2) if the neighbor is active
14656  // and a coarser one, ensure, that its
14657  // refine_flag is set 3) if the neighbor is
14658  // active and as refined along the face as our
14659  // current cell, make sure, that no
14660  // coarsen_flag is set. if we remove the
14661  // coarsen flag of our neighbor,
14662  // fix_coarsen_flags() makes sure, that the
14663  // mother cell will not be coarsened
14664  if (cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)->is_active())
14665  {
14666  if ((!has_periodic_neighbor &&
14667  cell->neighbor_is_coarser(i)) ||
14668  (has_periodic_neighbor &&
14669  cell->periodic_neighbor_is_coarser(i)))
14670  {
14671  if (cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14672  ->coarsen_flag_set())
14673  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14674  ->clear_coarsen_flag();
14675  // we'll set the refine flag for this
14676  // neighbor below. we note, that we
14677  // have changed something by setting
14678  // the changed flag to true. We do not
14679  // need to do so, if we just removed
14680  // the coarsen flag, as the changed
14681  // flag only indicates the need to
14682  // re-run the inner loop. however, we
14683  // only loop over cells flagged for
14684  // refinement here, so nothing to
14685  // worry about if we remove coarsen
14686  // flags
14687 
14688  if (dim == 2)
14689  {
14690  if (smooth_grid &
14691  allow_anisotropic_smoothing)
14692  changed =
14693  has_periodic_neighbor ?
14694  cell->periodic_neighbor(i)
14695  ->flag_for_face_refinement(
14696  cell
14697  ->periodic_neighbor_of_coarser_periodic_neighbor(
14698  i)
14699  .first,
14700  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::cut_x) :
14701  cell->neighbor(i)
14702  ->flag_for_face_refinement(
14703  cell
14704  ->neighbor_of_coarser_neighbor(
14705  i)
14706  .first,
14707  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::cut_x);
14708  else
14709  {
14710  if (!cell
14711  ->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(
14712  i)
14713  ->refine_flag_set())
14714  changed = true;
14715  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14716  ->set_refine_flag();
14717  }
14718  }
14719  else // i.e. if (dim==3)
14720  {
14721  // ugly situations might arise here,
14722  // consider the following situation, which
14723  // shows neighboring cells at the common
14724  // face, where the upper right element is
14725  // coarser at the given face. Now the upper
14726  // child element of the lower left wants to
14727  // refine according to cut_z, such that
14728  // there is a 'horizontal' refinement of the
14729  // face marked with #####
14730  //
14731  // / /
14732  // / /
14733  // *---------------*
14734  // | |
14735  // | |
14736  // | |
14737  // | |
14738  // | |
14739  // | | /
14740  // | |/
14741  // *---------------*
14742  //
14743  //
14744  // *---------------*
14745  // /| /|
14746  // / | ##### / |
14747  // | |
14748  // *---------------*
14749  // /| /|
14750  // / | / |
14751  // | |
14752  // *---------------*
14753  // / /
14754  // / /
14755  //
14756  // this introduces too many hanging nodes
14757  // and the neighboring (coarser) cell (upper
14758  // right) has to be refined. If it is only
14759  // refined according to cut_z, then
14760  // everything is ok:
14761  //
14762  // / /
14763  // / /
14764  // *---------------*
14765  // | |
14766  // | | /
14767  // | |/
14768  // *---------------*
14769  // | |
14770  // | | /
14771  // | |/
14772  // *---------------*
14773  //
14774  //
14775  // *---------------*
14776  // /| /|
14777  // / *---------------*
14778  // /| /|
14779  // *---------------*
14780  // /| /|
14781  // / | / |
14782  // | |
14783  // *---------------*
14784  // / /
14785  // / /
14786  //
14787  // if however the cell wants to refine
14788  // itself in an other way, or if we disallow
14789  // anisotropic smoothing, then simply
14790  // refining the neighbor isotropically is
14791  // not going to work, since this introduces
14792  // a refinement of face ##### with both
14793  // cut_x and cut_y, which is not possible:
14794  //
14795  // / / /
14796  // / / /
14797  // *-------*-------*
14798  // | | |
14799  // | | | /
14800  // | | |/
14801  // *-------*-------*
14802  // | | |
14803  // | | | /
14804  // | | |/
14805  // *-------*-------*
14806  //
14807  //
14808  // *---------------*
14809  // /| /|
14810  // / *---------------*
14811  // /| /|
14812  // *---------------*
14813  // /| /|
14814  // / | / |
14815  // | |
14816  // *---------------*
14817  // / /
14818  // / /
14819  //
14820  // thus, in this case we also need to refine
14821  // our current cell in the new direction:
14822  //
14823  // / / /
14824  // / / /
14825  // *-------*-------*
14826  // | | |
14827  // | | | /
14828  // | | |/
14829  // *-------*-------*
14830  // | | |
14831  // | | | /
14832  // | | |/
14833  // *-------*-------*
14834  //
14835  //
14836  // *-------*-------*
14837  // /| /| /|
14838  // / *-------*-------*
14839  // /| /| /|
14840  // *-------*-------*
14841  // /| / /|
14842  // / | / |
14843  // | |
14844  // *---------------*
14845  // / /
14846  // / /
14847 
14848  std::pair<unsigned int, unsigned int>
14849  nb_indices =
14850  has_periodic_neighbor ?
14851  cell
14852  ->periodic_neighbor_of_coarser_periodic_neighbor(
14853  i) :
14854  cell->neighbor_of_coarser_neighbor(i);
14855  unsigned int refined_along_x = 0,
14856  refined_along_y = 0,
14857  to_be_refined_along_x = 0,
14858  to_be_refined_along_y = 0;
14859 
14860  const int this_face_index =
14861  cell->face_index(i);
14862 
14863  // step 1: detect, along which axis the face
14864  // is currently refined
14865 
14866  // first, we need an iterator pointing to
14867  // the parent face. This requires a slight
14868  // detour in case the neighbor is behind a
14869  // periodic face.
14870  const auto parent_face = [&]() {
14871  if (has_periodic_neighbor)
14872  {
14873  const auto neighbor =
14874  cell->periodic_neighbor(i);
14875  const auto parent_face_no =
14876  neighbor
14877  ->periodic_neighbor_of_periodic_neighbor(
14878  nb_indices.first);
14879  auto parent =
14880  neighbor->periodic_neighbor(
14881  nb_indices.first);
14882  return parent->face(parent_face_no);
14883  }
14884  else
14885  return cell->neighbor(i)->face(
14886  nb_indices.first);
14887  }();
14888 
14889  if ((this_face_index ==
14890  parent_face->child_index(0)) ||
14891  (this_face_index ==
14892  parent_face->child_index(1)))
14893  {
14894  // this might be an
14895  // anisotropic child. get the
14896  // face refine case of the
14897  // neighbors face and count
14898  // refinements in x and y
14899  // direction.
14900  RefinementCase<dim - 1> frc =
14901  parent_face->refinement_case();
14902  if (frc & RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x)
14903  ++refined_along_x;
14904  if (frc & RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y)
14905  ++refined_along_y;
14906  }
14907  else
14908  // this has to be an isotropic
14909  // child
14910  {
14911  ++refined_along_x;
14912  ++refined_along_y;
14913  }
14914  // step 2: detect, along which axis the face
14915  // has to be refined given the current
14916  // refine flag
14917  RefinementCase<dim - 1> flagged_frc =
14918  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
14919  cell->refine_flag_set(),
14920  i,
14921  cell->face_orientation(i),
14922  cell->face_flip(i),
14923  cell->face_rotation(i));
14924  if (flagged_frc &
14925  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x)
14926  ++to_be_refined_along_x;
14927  if (flagged_frc &
14928  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y)
14929  ++to_be_refined_along_y;
14930 
14931  // step 3: set the refine flag of the
14932  // (coarser and active) neighbor.
14933  if ((smooth_grid &
14934  allow_anisotropic_smoothing) ||
14935  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14936  ->refine_flag_set())
14937  {
14938  if (refined_along_x +
14939  to_be_refined_along_x >
14940  1)
14941  changed |=
14942  cell
14943  ->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14944  ->flag_for_face_refinement(
14945  nb_indices.first,
14946  RefinementCase<dim -
14947  1>::cut_axis(0));
14948  if (refined_along_y +
14949  to_be_refined_along_y >
14950  1)
14951  changed |=
14952  cell
14953  ->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14954  ->flag_for_face_refinement(
14955  nb_indices.first,
14956  RefinementCase<dim -
14957  1>::cut_axis(1));
14958  }
14959  else
14960  {
14961  if (cell
14962  ->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14963  ->refine_flag_set() !=
14964  RefinementCase<
14965  dim>::isotropic_refinement)
14966  changed = true;
14967  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14968  ->set_refine_flag();
14969  }
14970 
14971  // step 4: if necessary (see above) add to
14972  // the refine flag of the current cell
14973  cell_iterator nb =
14974  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i);
14975  RefinementCase<dim - 1> nb_frc =
14976  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
14977  nb->refine_flag_set(),
14978  nb_indices.first,
14979  nb->face_orientation(nb_indices.first),
14980  nb->face_flip(nb_indices.first),
14981  nb->face_rotation(nb_indices.first));
14982  if ((nb_frc & RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x) &&
14983  !(refined_along_x ||
14984  to_be_refined_along_x))
14985  changed |= cell->flag_for_face_refinement(
14986  i,
14987  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::cut_axis(0));
14988  if ((nb_frc & RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y) &&
14989  !(refined_along_y ||
14990  to_be_refined_along_y))
14991  changed |= cell->flag_for_face_refinement(
14992  i,
14993  RefinementCase<dim - 1>::cut_axis(1));
14994  }
14995  } // if neighbor is coarser
14996  else // -> now the neighbor is not coarser
14997  {
14998  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i)
14999  ->clear_coarsen_flag();
15000  const unsigned int nb_nb =
15001  has_periodic_neighbor ?
15002  cell
15003  ->periodic_neighbor_of_periodic_neighbor(
15004  i) :
15005  cell->neighbor_of_neighbor(i);
15006  const cell_iterator neighbor =
15007  cell->neighbor_or_periodic_neighbor(i);
15008  RefinementCase<dim - 1> face_ref_case =
15009  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
15010  neighbor->refine_flag_set(),
15011  nb_nb,
15012  neighbor->face_orientation(nb_nb),
15013  neighbor->face_flip(nb_nb),
15014  neighbor->face_rotation(nb_nb));
15015  RefinementCase<dim - 1> needed_face_ref_case =
15016  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
15017  cell->refine_flag_set(),
15018  i,
15019  cell->face_orientation(i),
15020  cell->face_flip(i),
15021  cell->face_rotation(i));
15022  // if the neighbor wants to refine the
15023  // face with cut_x and we want cut_y
15024  // or vice versa, we have to refine
15025  // isotropically at the given face
15026  if ((face_ref_case ==
15027  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x &&
15028  needed_face_ref_case ==
15029  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y) ||
15030  (face_ref_case ==
15031  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y &&
15032  needed_face_ref_case ==
15033  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x))
15034  {
15035  changed = cell->flag_for_face_refinement(
15036  i, face_ref_case);
15037  neighbor->flag_for_face_refinement(
15038  nb_nb, needed_face_ref_case);
15039  }
15040  }
15041  }
15042  else //-> the neighbor is not active
15043  {
15044  RefinementCase<dim - 1>
15045  face_ref_case = cell->face(i)->refinement_case(),
15046  needed_face_ref_case =
15047  GeometryInfo<dim>::face_refinement_case(
15048  cell->refine_flag_set(),
15049  i,
15050  cell->face_orientation(i),
15051  cell->face_flip(i),
15052  cell->face_rotation(i));
15053  // if the face is refined with cut_x and
15054  // we want cut_y or vice versa, we have to
15055  // refine isotropically at the given face
15056  if ((face_ref_case == RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x &&
15057  needed_face_ref_case ==
15058  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y) ||
15059  (face_ref_case == RefinementCase<dim>::cut_y &&
15060  needed_face_ref_case ==
15061  RefinementCase<dim>::cut_x))
15062  changed =
15063  cell->flag_for_face_refinement(i,
15064  face_ref_case);
15065  }
15066  }
15067  }
15068  }
15069  }
15070 
15072  // STEP 7:
15073  // take care that no double refinement
15074  // is done at each line in 3d or higher
15075  // dimensions.
15076  this->policy->prepare_refinement_dim_dependent(*this);
15077 
15079  // STEP 8:
15080  // make sure that all children of each
15081  // cell are either flagged for coarsening
15082  // or none of the children is
15083  fix_coarsen_flags();
15084  // get the refinement and coarsening
15085  // flags
15086  std::vector<bool> flags_after_loop[2];
15087  save_coarsen_flags(flags_after_loop[0]);
15088  save_refine_flags(flags_after_loop[1]);
15089 
15090  // find out whether something was
15091  // changed in this loop
15092  mesh_changed_in_this_loop =
15093  ((flags_before_loop[0] != flags_after_loop[0]) ||
15094  (flags_before_loop[1] != flags_after_loop[1]));
15095 
15096  // set the flags for the next loop
15097  // already
15098  flags_before_loop[0].swap(flags_after_loop[0]);
15099  flags_before_loop[1].swap(flags_after_loop[1]);
15100  }
15101  while (mesh_changed_in_this_loop);
15102 
15103 
15104  // find out whether something was really changed in this
15105  // function. Note that @p{flags_before_loop} represents the state
15106  // after the last loop, i.e. the present state
15107  return ((flags_before[0] != flags_before_loop[0]) ||
15108  (flags_before[1] != flags_before_loop[1]));
15109 }
15110 
15111 
15112 
15113 template <int dim, int spacedim>
15114 void
15115 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::write_bool_vector(
15116  const unsigned int magic_number1,
15117  const std::vector<bool> &v,
15118  const unsigned int magic_number2,
15119  std::ostream & out)
15120 {
15121  const unsigned int N = v.size();
15122  unsigned char * flags = new unsigned char[N / 8 + 1];
15123  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < N / 8 + 1; ++i)
15124  flags[i] = 0;
15125 
15126  for (unsigned int position = 0; position < N; ++position)
15127  flags[position / 8] |= (v[position] ? (1 << (position % 8)) : 0);
15128 
15129  AssertThrow(out, ExcIO());
15130 
15131  // format:
15132  // 0. magic number
15133  // 1. number of flags
15134  // 2. the flags
15135  // 3. magic number
15136  out << magic_number1 << ' ' << N << std::endl;
15137  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < N / 8 + 1; ++i)
15138  out << static_cast<unsigned int>(flags[i]) << ' ';
15139 
15140  out << std::endl << magic_number2 << std::endl;
15141 
15142  delete[] flags;
15143 
15144  AssertThrow(out, ExcIO());
15145 }
15146 
15147 
15148 template <int dim, int spacedim>
15149 void
15150 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::read_bool_vector(const unsigned int magic_number1,
15151  std::vector<bool> &v,
15152  const unsigned int magic_number2,
15153  std::istream & in)
15154 {
15155  AssertThrow(in, ExcIO());
15156 
15157  unsigned int magic_number;
15158  in >> magic_number;
15159  AssertThrow(magic_number == magic_number1, ExcGridReadError());
15160 
15161  unsigned int N;
15162  in >> N;
15163  v.resize(N);
15164 
15165  unsigned char * flags = new unsigned char[N / 8 + 1];
15166  unsigned short int tmp;
15167  for (unsigned int i = 0; i < N / 8 + 1; ++i)
15168  {
15169  in >> tmp;
15170  flags[i] = tmp;
15171  }
15172 
15173  for (unsigned int position = 0; position != N; ++position)
15174  v[position] = (flags[position / 8] & (1 << (position % 8)));
15175 
15176  in >> magic_number;
15177  AssertThrow(magic_number == magic_number2, ExcGridReadError());
15178 
15179  delete[] flags;
15180 
15181  AssertThrow(in, ExcIO());
15182 }
15183 
15184 
15185 
15186 template <int dim, int spacedim>
15187 std::size_t
15188 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::memory_consumption() const
15189 {
15190  std::size_t mem = 0;
15191  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(levels);
15192  for (const auto &level : levels)
15193  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(*level);
15194  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(vertices);
15195  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(vertices_used);
15196  mem += sizeof(manifold);
15197  mem += sizeof(smooth_grid);
15198  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(number_cache);
15199  mem += sizeof(faces);
15200  if (faces)
15201  mem += MemoryConsumption::memory_consumption(*faces);
15202 
15203  return mem;
15204 }
15205 
15206 
15207 
15208 template <int dim, int spacedim>
15209 Triangulation<dim, spacedim>::DistortedCellList::~DistortedCellList() noexcept =
15210  default;
15211 
15212 
15213 // explicit instantiations
15214 #include "tria.inst"
15215 
15216 DEAL_II_NAMESPACE_CLOSE
SubCellData::boundary_lines
std::vector< CellData< 1 > > boundary_lines
Definition: tria_description.h:173
Triangulation::Signals::copy
boost::signals2::signal< void(const Triangulation< dim, spacedim > &destination_tria)> copy
Definition: tria.h:1417
internal::TriangulationImplementation::PolicyWrapper::coarsening_allowed
bool coarsening_allowed(const typename Triangulation< dim, spacedim >::cell_iterator &cell) override
Definition: tria.cc:1696
Triangulation::eliminate_unrefined_islands
Definition: tria.h:770
Utilities::lower_bound
Iterator lower_bound(Iterator first, Iterator last, const T &val)
Definition: utilities.h:959
unsigned int
ArrayView
Definition: array_view.h:77
full_matrix.h
internal::TriangulationImplementation::Implementation::update_neighbors
static void update_neighbors(Triangulation< dim, spacedim > &triangulation)
Definition: tria.cc:2116
Triangulation::number_cache
::internal::TriangulationImplementation::NumberCache< dim > number_cache
Definition: tria.h:3120
Triangulation::n_active_cells
unsigned int n_active_cells() const
Definition: tria.cc:12645

internal::TriangulationImplementation::DeclException5
DeclException5(ExcInteriorQuadCantBeBoundary, int, int, int, int, types::boundary_id,<< "The input data for creating a triangulation contained "<< "information about a quad with indices "<< arg1<< ", "<< arg2<< ", "<< arg3<< ", and "<< arg4<< " that is described to have boundary indicator "<< static_cast< int >(arg5)<< ". However, this is an internal quad not located on the "<< "boundary. You cannot assign a boundary indicator to it."<< std::endl<< std::endl<< "If this happened at a place where you call "<< "Triangulation::create_triangulation() yourself, you need "<< "to check the SubCellData object you pass to this function."<< std::endl<< std::endl<< "If this happened in a place where you are reading a mesh "<< "from a file, then you need to investigate why such a quad "<< "ended up in the input file. A typical case is a geometry "<< "that consisted of multiple parts and for which the mesh "<< "generator program assumes that the interface between "<< "two parts is a boundary when that isn't supposed to be "<< "the case, or where the mesh generator simply assigns "<< "'geometry indicators' to quads at the surface of "<< "a part that are not supposed to be interpreted as "<< "'boundary indicators'.")
